LanguageData.BakerRifle.label: Baker Rifle
LanguageData.BakerRifle.description: Baker rifle. Standard weapon assigned to rifle regiments in the British army. Highly accurate, but require an extensive reload time. Muzzleloaded, with a slow reload time but devastating power behind the bullet. Bullets fired from these weapons were often lead, which in turn resulted in many infections and amputations from wounds caused by these weapons.
LanguageData.BakerRifle.tools.bayonet.label: bayonet
LanguageData.BakerRifle.tools.stock.label: stock
LanguageData.BakerRifle.verbs.Verb_Shoot.label: Baker Rifle
LanguageData.BritishOfficerSword.label: British Officer Sword
LanguageData.BritishOfficerSword.description: Standard pattern British Officer sword. Exceptionally sharp, and extremely well made.
LanguageData.BritishOfficerSword.tools.handle.label: handle
LanguageData.BritishOfficerSword.tools.blade.label: blade
LanguageData.BritishOfficerSword.tools.point.label: point
LanguageData.BrownBessMusket.label: Brown Bess Musket
LanguageData.BrownBessMusket.description: Land pattern Brown Bess musket. Heavier than its french counterpart, resulting in a slightly longer reload time but more accurate fire. Muzzleloaded, with a slow reload time but devastating power behind the bullet. Bullets fired from these weapons were often lead, which in turn resulted in many infections and amputations from wounds caused by these weapons.
LanguageData.BrownBessMusket.tools.bayonet.label: bayonet
LanguageData.BrownBessMusket.tools.stock.label: stock
LanguageData.BrownBessMusket.verbs.Verb_Shoot.label: Brown Bess Musket
LanguageData.Bullet_Musket.label: MinieBullet
LanguageData.Bullet_Rifle.label: MinieBullet
LanguageData.CharlevilleMusket.label: Charleville Musket
LanguageData.CharlevilleMusket.description: Standard pattern Charleville musket, designed in 1777 as a standard infantry musket. Muzzleloaded, with a slow reload time but devastating power behind the bullet. Bullets fired from these weapons were often lead, which in turn resulted in many infections and amputations from wounds caused by these weapons.
LanguageData.CharlevilleMusket.tools.bayonet.label: bayonet
LanguageData.CharlevilleMusket.tools.stock.label: stock
LanguageData.CharlevilleMusket.verbs.Verb_Shoot.label: Charleville Musket
LanguageData.FrenchBriquet.label: French Infantry Briquet
LanguageData.FrenchBriquet.description: Standard French infantry blade designed as a sidearm in place of the Charleville musket.
LanguageData.FrenchBriquet.tools.handle.label: handle
LanguageData.FrenchBriquet.tools.blade.label: blade
LanguageData.FrenchBriquet.tools.point.label: point
LanguageData.Potsdam.label: Potsdam 1809 Musket
LanguageData.Potsdam.description: New model musket replacing the ancient 1740 Frederick musket. Lighter and faster to reload than other weapons, the cartridge is slightly smaller and wounds somewhat less, but carries a slightly better range than French and British counterparts. Bullets fired from these weapons were often lead, which in turn resulted in many infections and amputations from wounds caused by these weapons.
LanguageData.Potsdam.tools.bayonet.label: bayonet
LanguageData.Potsdam.tools.stock.label: stock
LanguageData.Potsdam.verbs.Verb_Shoot.label: Potsdam 1809 Musket
LanguageData.PrussianBriquet.label: Prussian Briquet
LanguageData.PrussianBriquet.description: Standard Prussian infantry blade designed as a sidearm or infantry officer weapon.
LanguageData.PrussianBriquet.tools.handle.label: handle
LanguageData.PrussianBriquet.tools.blade.label: blade
LanguageData.PrussianBriquet.tools.point.label: point
